ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: An appreciation of writing about dance and exposure to trying to do it
Learned more about critiquing dance and how to appreciate different forms of dance
I learned more about how to express the non-verbal with words -- explaining and articulating the images and feelings created by dance.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths:
- trips are cool
- very unique
- plenty of opportunity to share in class and participate
- anonymity throughout the course made us comfortable with feedback
- an awesome assignment where you apply dance writing to something else of your choice

Cons:
- pretty monotonous
- during process for final exercise, only got one round of feedback when there could have been space to partner up a few times before and after edits
- a lot of paper waste created at end of course
- grading was kind of harsh for something so niche and novel to students

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you're interested in dance, definitely take this class! I loved getting to see live performances and also just generally break down a dance in seminar conversation. The course is, however, mostly writing/workshopping the writing--so be prepared for that. I felt that this was a class where it was very easy to do pretty well, but not that easy to do very well. It's a very particular kind of writing (different from analytic essays, for instance) and Brian is THE expert in it. He gives tons of feedback, but if you're looking for a "gut" writing class this probably isn't it.

Yes I would absolutely recommend this class. I feel like Professor Seibert is very good at what he does and that inspired me to try my hand at writing dance. While writing about dance is a huge challenge, I think Professor Seibert helped ease us into the new territory.

I would recommend that other students shop this course and really think hard about whether or not they would remain interested and engaged in the activities of the first class meeting for an entire semester (because it doesn't change). But, if a student is really into dance and has time to accommodate the trips to the city (they are long and tiring and often get back to New Haven very late), I would recommend they look into it.
